Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Baseline Survey of the Lower Xingu River Rapids, Brazil: a Highly Diverse, Globally Unique, and Immediately Imperiled Ecosystem
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Amazon Basin is Earth's most biodiverse watershed, yet much remains unknown about species diversity, population structures, biogeographic ranges, and ecological and evolutionary processes. This project will document and analyze the aquatic biodiversity of a 130 km-long anastomosing maze of high-energy rapids in Brazil: the Lower Xingu River Rapids (LXRR) and adjacent stretches of the Xingu. The LXRR faces imminent change from its wild state to both dewatered and lentic, impounded habitats following completion of the Belo Monte hydroelectric dam. New comprehensive specimen collections of fishes, crustaceans and mollusks and associated data will be used to address key questions in taxonomy, evolution and ecology, and will provide a permanent record (placed at US and Brazilian museums) and environmental baseline of life within the LXRR to assess future anthropogenic impacts.

This project will advance understanding of the contribution that large river rapids make to tropical biodiversity and productivity, and will train a wide range aquatic scientists needed for the future study, protection and restoration of these habitats. An on-line, publicly accessible illustrated guide to the identification of LXRR fishes and invertebrates will be created. Two postdoctoral scientists will be supported. Training and learning opportunities will be offered for high school, undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The iXingu Project is a US-Brazilian effort to study and document the aquatic biological and ecological diversity of the longest stretch of large river rapids in South America: Volta Grande do Xingu. The Xingu River is the Amazon’s third largest tributary and largest clear water tributary with a catchment area almost the size of France. Over the course of 130 river kilometers, the Middle Xingu falls 90 meters and changes course by about 90 degrees in each of three major bends. As it enters Volta Grande, the Xingu unravels into a complex labyrinth of watery channels, powerful rapids, and low waterfalls formed and bounded by the ancient rocks of the northern Brazilian Shield. Downstream of Volta Grande, the Xingu slows and widens into an estuary-like ria as it flows over softer sediments to its confluence with the Amazon. 

The Volta Grande Rapids support unique and species-rich assemblages of aquatic organisms, especially fishes. In 2011, however, the Brazilian government approved construction of Belo Monte, a run-of-the-river megadam that had been proposed for the Middle Xingu as early as 1975. The final plans included two major dams: Pimental for creating a reservoir in the Xingu channel and Belo Monte for receiving water diverted from the reservoir. Located in the heart of Volta Grande, Pimental would have a tremendous impact on the Xingu channel by flooding about 80 river kilometers of rapids (upstream impact) and dewatering another 90 river kilometers of rapids (downstream impact). 

The major goal of the iXingu Project was to inventory the aquatic biodiversity of the Middle Xingu prior to its disruption by the Belo Monte Megadam which became operational in late 2015. Over the course of six expeditions (pilot, 3 full, 2 follow-up) from 2012 to 2016, a total of 58 professional scientists, students and local guides sampled Volta Grande and adjacent upstream and downstream stretches of the Xingu spanning a total of 410 river kilometers. Our team collected, identified and vouchered nearly 50,000 specimens representing about 518 species of aquatic organisms including fishes (450 species), crustaceans (30 species), mollusks (30 species) and sponges (8 species). Those specimens have contributed to the descriptions of at least 40 new species including one shrimp, one sponge, two mussels, and 36 fishes. 

Our work revealed species-rich communities that are unique to the Volta Grande Rapids and are largely replaced by communities of more cosmopolitan Amazonian species in the Lower Xingu Ria. Tissue samples taken during the project have contributed to genetic studies of evolutionary relationships and ecological studies of trophic relationships among groups of fishes, crustaceans and mussels. The biodiversity and ecological findings of the iXingu Project provide critical baseline data for tracking changes in aquatic communities and ecosystem processes prior to the altered regime imposed by the Belo Monte Megadam. 

Beyond scientific work, the iXingu Project strengthened important and productive ties between biologists in the US and Brazil. Our collaborative work has raised public awareness of the rich, complex and unique assembly of aquatic organisms inhabiting the Xingu Rapids via popular articles and books, lectures and presentations, websites and social media, and public programs and displays. At the same time, the iXingu Project called attention to the greatest threat to large tropical river rapids: Megadams.
